articles.headline: Senate Abandons Automaker Bailout Bid
articles.snippet: Senate Republicans refused to support a bill endorsed by the White House and Congressional Democrats.
articles.abstract: Senate Republicans refused to support a bill endorsed by the White House and Congressional Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday night abandoned efforts to fashion a government rescue of the American automobile industry, as Senate Republicans refused to support a bill endorsed by the White House and Congressional Democrats.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Cholera Epidemic Sweeping Across Crumbling Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: Zimbabwe’s public services are failing as an epidemic rages — but Robert G. Mugabe won’t resign.
articles.abstract: Zimbabwe’s public services are failing as an epidemic rages — but Robert G. Mugabe won’t resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Cholera swept through the five youngest children in the Chigudu family with cruel and bewildering haste.

articles.headline: Japanese Companies Still Invest in Themselves
articles.snippet: Many Japanese companies are cutting back less than their rivals, investing instead for the eventual end of the downturn.
articles.abstract: Many Japanese companies are cutting back less than their rivals, investing instead for the eventual end of the downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAKAI, Japan  Despite the rapidly slowing economy, an army of cranes still moves busily above the archipelago of factories that Sharp is building in this gritty port.

articles.headline: Bank of America to Cut 35,000 Jobs Over 3 Years
articles.snippet: The company said that the cuts reflected the pending merger with Merrill Lynch and the weak economy.
articles.abstract: The company said that the cuts reflected the pending merger with Merrill Lynch and the weak economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America said on Thursday that it planned to cut 30,000 to 35,000 positions  among the largest layoffs ever  over the next three years as it digests its acquisition of Merrill Lynch. That could amount to more than 11 percent of the combined firms’ global work force of 308,000.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Prominent Trader Accused of Defrauding Clients
articles.snippet: Charges say the scheme engineered by Bernard L. Madoff caused $50 billion in losses.
articles.abstract: Charges say the scheme engineered by Bernard L. Madoff caused $50 billion in losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, his name is legendary. With money he had made as a lifeguard on the beaches of Long Island, he built a trading powerhouse that had prospered for more than four decades. At age 70, he had become an influential spokesman for the traders who are the hidden gears of the marketplace.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Fury Builds Over Crisis at Banks
articles.snippet: Efforts by the big banks to point the finger of blame elsewhere seem to be failing at the same time public anger is growing.
articles.abstract: Efforts by the big banks to point the finger of blame elsewhere seem to be failing at the same time public anger is growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street backlash is under way. If it grows strong enough, it could end with some bankers facing criminal trials.

articles.headline: Inside Europe’s High-Living Wax Cartel
articles.snippet: Documents reveal how a group of oil companies met to control the price of paraffin in Europe.
articles.abstract: Documents reveal how a group of oil companies met to control the price of paraffin in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Surrounded by a moat and four watchtowers, the ancient Château d’Ermenonville is not the kind of place one would associate with a product as mundane as paraffin.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Pensions Get a Reprieve in Congress
articles.snippet: Companies whose pension funds suffered big losses this year will not have to replenish the money quickly under a relief measure that flew through the Senate.
articles.abstract: Companies whose pension funds suffered big losses this year will not have to replenish the money quickly under a relief measure that flew through the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies whose pension funds suffered big losses this year will not have to replenish the money quickly under a relief measure that flew through the Senate Thursday and will next go to the president for his signature.

articles.headline: Auto Suppliers Share Anxiety Over a Bailout
articles.snippet: Auto suppliers are teetering on the verge of bankruptcy, and can’t extend credit much longer.
articles.abstract: Auto suppliers are teetering on the verge of bankruptcy, and can’t extend credit much longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  With Congress failing to agree on a bailout for Detroit, the odds that General Motors and Chrysler will be insolvent by year’s end are growing rapidly.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Obama to Air Any Staff Talks About Senate Seat
articles.snippet: A grand jury was weighing evidence against Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, and an Illinois state senator said he had felt pressured toward a quid pro quo agreement.
articles.abstract: A grand jury was weighing evidence against Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, and an Illinois state senator said he had felt pressured toward a quid pro quo agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  President-elect Barack Obama pledged Thursday to disclose any interaction between his transition team and the office of besieged Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois, while declaring again that he and his staff had no involvement in deal-making over an appointment to his vacated Senate seat.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Monica Davey

articles.headline: White House Ready to Aid Auto Industry
articles.snippet: The Bush administration said it would consider dipping into the $700 billion rescue fund to help automakers.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration said it would consider dipping into the $700 billion rescue fund to help automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Bush administration said on Friday that it was prepared to intervene to prevent the collapse of General Motors and Chrysler after Republican senators blocked a compromise proposal to rescue the automakers.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and David M. Herszenhorn
